text:
When I speak with customer
chief information security

officers (CISOs) as well as compliance
officers and other security

professionals, they are often
interested in how they should

think about their compliance
program as they move their

workloads to Amazon Web Services
(AWS).

As with anything new, there
is a learning curve.

But as customers become more
acquainted with compliance

on AWS, they're excited about
the opportunities available.

Here are three areas that I typically
focus on in those conversations.

Number one, understand
the AWS shared responsibility
model.

AWS provides secure, resilient,
and compliant infrastructure

and services for the customer
to run their business.

Customers are responsible
for the security and compliance

of the architectures
they build on top of AWS.

AWS supports 98 security
standards and compliance

certifications for AWS services
and infrastructure,

and customers can inherit
many of those controls into
their own compliance programs.

While customers are delighted
by the reduced compliance

burden, the customer must still
implement and maintain other

controls for what they build
on top of AWS.
Number two, education.
Read the compliance reports.

As an AWS customer, you have
access to all of our compliance
reports through AWS Artifact.

Read them and understand
the controls that you're inheriting

and which services are in scope
for a particular compliance
standard.

Then, calculate the delta between
what you're inheriting

from AWS and what is left to do
inside your own programs.

And if you're new to the cloud,
consider attending the Cloud

Audit Academy to sharpen
your skills and assess workloads
in the cloud.

Number three, become familiar
with compliance-focused
tools at AWS.

Consider the capabilities
available in AWS Config,

AWS CloudTrail, AWS Audit Manager,
and others as you build your
compliance programs.

I've just begun to scratch
the surface of the exciting

opportunities for compliance
and audit professionals
using AWS.

Please use the following
links for more information.
Thank you.
